content:
I have few questions:

  • What is a 'zulip'? If nothing, what should it be?
  • Why 'green' and what green? We should use the brand color more consistently.
  • Why an octopus? Is it a zulip, a mascot or just one of many ideas?
Zulip is a made up word that rhymes with "tulip." The "Z" in zulip is an homage to an older chat program called Zephyr that was popular at MIT.
I think green was just somebody's favorite color at one point. :)
The octupus is an unofficial Zulip mascot/inside-joke from Recurse Center, and it's based off of the fact that the emoji can hold things above its head.
We are intending to make it more of an official mascot, with appearances in product pages (etc.)

As far as "soft branding," I don't know of too many Zulip things besides the octopus. When you look at a bigger project like Python, there are lots of Monty Python references (spam/eggs) and snake references. I'm not aware of anything similar in Zulip-land. And we've never really done anything with tulips ( ).
There's a little bit of "z" identity in the codebase, with things like "zerver" and "zproject."
Now many things start to make sense...
always wondered about "zerver"
I also suspected that Zulip has something to do with tulips, though I haven't seen any flowers in the graphics ;)
We've also started going with an underwater/sea-creatures theme for the 500/404 pages, image not found, etc., which I like.

As for the green color:
https://img-9gag-fun.9cache.com/photo/106661_700b.jpg

Words with "z" in it (some spellings only apply to US):

amaZing
harmoniZe
daZZle
siZe
blaZing
There is definitely a need to specify the color more concretely than 'green', a blue-green tint can suggest water, while more warm green suggest eco-friendly things.
In that sense, a brand color is just one hex value, and not all possible permutations of green which are more than 1/4rd of all colors.
Agreed. We've been going with a more blue-green tint.
I've been thinking of brand color as more a hue than a hex value, e.g. https://medium.com/@erikdkennedy/color-in-ui-design-a-practical-framework-e18cacd97f9e

That refers to color palette choices in UI. That is very different than a 'brand' color. If you don't choose a color, then you don't own a color. I mean it is similar to saying 'any word that starts with z can be used in place of zulip'.

I am using the same technique that is detailed in the article, for example the constant BRAND_COLOR can be 20% darker for some element, and then 50% transparent for other element. The key word here is 'constant'
We have a #marketing stream that we may want to either retire or use for this type of conversation.

constant brand color that you apply variations to

Makes sense

i like the idea of using a blue-green tint as it is less "basic" than a simple green. fits the underwater theme quite nicely! not sure how we could integrate tulips into it though :') should I try colouring different "fake" branding element mockups (t-shirt, banner, stickers) with different shades of blue-green to see what comes out nicest, or is there an easier way to proceed on this?
